title: Interdisciplinary Insights: Bridging media and STEM Making a podcast.

So what is a podcast? So a podcast is a
series of spoken word audio episodes
focused on a particular topic or theme.
So it tends to be about one particular
um one particular process idea topic or
a particular um discipline or a domain
or a particular area of research. So
some of you might be here because you

we might be talking about a kind of
singular audio experience like a feature
a kind of doc audio documentary. Um that

it's interchangeable language right? So,
the idea of a podcast generally is that

it's meant a conversation is um a
podcast is meant to be engaging to
listen to a little bit more
traditionally aligned with how radio

conversational. Now, there are two main
groups that we're going to put podcast
in today. They are narrativebased and

you are focused on telling the story of

like this podcast series serial or um
America this American life or there's
multiple true crime um podcast around
where you're unpacking over a number of

in that other than you. You may not be

you may include a couple of interviews

fair few interviews. So, it's up to you.
That form is very flexible. Um so, the
other option, the other more common one,
which is the one we'll be looking a

a interviewbased podcast. And usually
that's when um you are interviewing
someone different every week or a couple
of different people around a different

really focusing on that interview. That
is the main part of it. It's not about

that I start off here, but you can

with thinking or asking about why or why
are you interested in this particular
thing to my guest. How did you start?
Where did you where you know how did you
come to this? How did you get involved?
What drew you into this particular
project or this particular idea? So, I'm
kind of thinking about in my head why
this why this thing? Why are you

now more about the people and the

I'll always cover some sort of

and hear that they've mentioned that it
was hard to get funding. So, I'll say,
oh, so how how did you get the funding?
That must have been very challenging.
What's some advice for people who may be
facing the challenge of getting funding?
So, I'm unpack and ask about the

really thinking about um challenges advi
it's sort of a way of getting advice for

beta's science communication project um
with those podcasts we're looking at

talking to um science students about

We might ask something to start off

in your where do you do your research?
Do you work in the lab? Do you work with

in the answer. And that's great. I don't

what we're doing is listening for an

information comes out. And we might ask
because they're science students that's
in might be in a laboratory, what

What do you need to do to succeed in

like, well, what equipment do you use?
lets us kind of pull that out a little
bit and let them understand and

what's the best way to manage your work

And then we might go on to ask, what

Why did you undertake this? Did you have

How do you think it might look and work

um project unit and also to get them
used to talking about their project in
to people that may not be used to
hearing about it as well. Um, so a trick
with this that journalists use a lot is
they'll often um get their interviewees
to repeat the question as a statement at
the beginning of their response. And um
I've got this great example from Corey,
one of our um podcast teachers. Um when
if I want to know what their journey,
say they're a ballet dancer, I want to
know where they where they started. So I
might ask, well, where did your journey
of ballet begin? What I would like them
to do, so I will need to advise them on
this before the session is to repeat
that question in a way that makes it
easier for me to edit later on audio. So
I'd say, can you repeat the second half
of my question as a statement? So I'll
give them that example. Well, where did
your journey of ballet begin? They might
say, well, my journey journey of ballet
began when? And they tell us that story.
And that gets used in TV a lot, too. So,
you're kind of um giving a fuller
answer, encouraging them to give you a
fuller sentence answer so that it's
easier for editing. Now, the challenge
with that is that it's not always
feeling naturally conversational. So,
sometimes you may not want to use that.
So, but it's a good it's a good way of
creating some space for you to edit. Um
so, I'll chat to you now and I won't I

you'll find that most of them fit under

expecting you to point them in the

that you've got some questions prepared.
You can um do them quite specific or you

did you start your uh university degree
or you could say that's quite specific
or you could use something like um you

university degree? How did you come to
this? You know when did when did it all
happen for you? So you can ask the same

specific information coming back or you
can ask it in a way that is a little bit

two different approaches to the same
getting the same information. Uh so it's
up to you if you want to ask really

bit more open. And um Jamie and Omera
has a great um session which I've
included in the um in the video
resources about creating cheats cheat
sheets. So um a a sheet of information
that has a little bit about of the

what the name of their project is or
what the name of their particular um
film that they've done is or their

it's good to have those kind of notes
with you when you're doing the interview
just so you can refer back to them. Um
and we've got some examples of those
that we can share with you. And when
you're interviewing, you need to make
sure that you are um actually listening
and responding to what people are
saying. You don't want to just
interview, ask a question, wait till
they finish, then ask the next question,
and wait till they finish. That's not a
conversation. Um so you want to listen
and not be afraid to move into asking
other things. You can go off on a bit of
a tangent if that's if there's something
that the person has said that you're
interviewing that sounds like you maybe
your audience might want to know more
about it or that sounds a little bit
more interesting than maybe what your
next question was going to be. So you
can take a a moment to diverge and um
move into a side topic if that's where
the conversation goes naturally. You can
always edit it out if it didn't work.
So, it's important to follow the
conversation.
And um also, and this is really hard,
it's really hard to try not to make too
many noises when you're interviewing
someone, be careful not to say, "Yeah,
yeah. Oh, definitely." Or, "M" Because
what happens is it makes it harder to
edit. And it also means that while
they're talking, you're going to they're
we're going to be hearing your voice
coming in a lot. So, it takes a lot of
practice to actually not say much and
not give much affirmation back when
you're or much confirmation and
acknowledgement when you're interviewing
someone. Um, so it takes a bit of
practice. So, just remember, try to nod
and not go too much. But sometimes you
have to, so that's okay. But just
balance that out. you'll find when you
do it and you try to edit, you'll never

also uh, don't be afraid to um,
interject with your own um, additional

definitely um share your experiences

what you're doing with the podcast,
that's fine. So, that is coming back to
the philosophy of it's a conversation,
it's a sharing, but remember it's not
about you, it's about your interviewee,
right?
Um, so try to leave a bit of a beat of
silence in between your questions or
your comments. Try not to talk over the
person because that means you're going
to find it really hard to slice and edit

your voice overlapping. So if for
instance when I'm giving a lecture I'm
now I can see I've got my next slide in
front of me after this one. So I can
naturally segue into the next slide.
However, that would cause a problem if I

um, okay, that that's great. Thank you.
So, my next question is that little
space makes it easier for you to edit
the audio and to move things around. So,
um, silence is death if it's too long in
audio, but silence is golden if it's
just long enough that it lets you, um,
create an edit space that sounds natural
because if you don't, you'll end up
cutting off words um, of the beginning
or the ends of sentences.
